Memorize this context: This is the SRS for the current project: Software Requirements Specification (SRS) for GiveMap: Charity Locations Web Application 1. Introduction 1.1 Purpose The purpose of this document is to define the Software Requirements Specification (SRS) for a map-based web application, GiveMap, that enables organizations such as universities, colleges, and non-profit communities to locate and share areas in need of charity within Vietnam. This document outlines the necessary features, functionalities, and business modules required to develop a functional and user-friendly application.
1.2 Scope This web application aims to provide a platform for users to share and discover locations in need of donations. The application will feature a map-based interface where users can pinpoint locations, describe the needs, and share them within the community. The pilot stage of the application will focus on locations within Vietnam only.
1.3 Definitions, Acronyms, and Abbreviations SRS: Software Requirements Specification NGO: Non-Governmental Organization UI: User Interface UX: User Experience API: Application Programming Interface 1.4 References Google Maps API Documentation Bootstrap Documentation 2. Overall Description 2.1 Product Perspective The application will be a standalone web-based platform. It will leverage modern web technologies and APIs to provide an interactive and intuitive user experience. The primary user base includes organizations planning charity activities and individuals looking to contribute to these efforts.
2.2 Product Functions User registration and authentication Map-based location sharing Description and categorization of needs at each location Search and filter functionality for locations Community feedback and rating system Admin dashboard for managing users and locations Needs and donations management 2.3 User Classes and Characteristics General Users: Individuals who can view and share locations in need of charity. Organizations: Entities such as universities, colleges, and NGOs that plan and organize charity activities. Administrators: Users with elevated privileges to manage the application, including user accounts and location data. 2.4 Operating Environment Web browsers: Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge Server: Linux-based server with Apache or Nginx Database: MySQL or PostgreSQL APIs: Google Maps API for location services 2.5 Design and Implementation Constraints The application must comply with data protection regulations in Vietnam. The system should be scalable to handle increasing amounts of data and user traffic. 2.6 Assumptions and Dependencies Users will have internet access to use the web application. Google Maps API will be used for the map-based interface. 3. Specific Requirements 3.1 Functional Requirements 3.1.1 User Registration and Authentication Users must be able to register using email and password. Users must be able to log in and log out securely. Password recovery options must be available. 3.1.2 Map-Based Location Sharing Users must be able to drop pins on a map to indicate locations in need. Users must be able to provide descriptions, categories, and images for each location. The map interface should be intuitive and responsive. 3.1.3 Location Details Each location must have a detail page displaying the description, category, and images. Users must be able to comment on and rate locations. 3.1.4 Search and Filter Functionality Users must be able to search for locations based on keywords. Users must be able to filter locations by category, urgency, and date added. 3.1.5 Community Feedback Users must be able to rate and provide feedback on each location. Feedback must be visible to other users to foster a transparent community. 3.1.6 Admin Dashboard Admins must be able to view, edit, and delete user accounts. Admins must be able to manage location data, including adding, editing, and removing locations. Admins must be able to generate reports on user activity and location data. 3.1.7 Needs and Donations Management Add Needs: Users must be able to specify what people at each location are in need of (e.g., food, clothing, educational materials). Needs must be categorized and described in detail. Users must be able to upload images related to the needs. Each need must have an urgency level (e.g., high, medium, low). Offer Donations: Users must be able to specify what they can donate to a location (e.g., specific items, monetary donations). Users must be able to view a list of current needs and choose what to donate based on these needs. Users must be able to provide a description of their donations and expected delivery times. Donation Tracking: Users must be able to track the status of their donations (e.g., pending, delivered, received). The system must notify users of the status changes of their donations. 3.2 Non-Functional Requirements 3.2.1 Performance Requirements The application must load within 3 seconds for an optimal user experience. The system must handle at least 1,000 concurrent users. 3.2.2 Security Requirements User data must be encrypted during transmission and storage. The application must implement measures to prevent unauthorized access. 3.2.3 Usability Requirements The UI must be intuitive and easy to navigate. The application must be accessible to users with disabilities. 3.2.4 Scalability Requirements The system architecture must support horizontal scaling to accommodate growth. 3.2.5 Notification Requirements The application must send notifications to users when: A new need is added to a location they follow. A donation offer is made for a need they posted. The status of their donation changes. 3.3 External Interface Requirements 3.3.1 User Interfaces Registration/Login Page Home Page with Map Interface Location Detail Page Search/Filter Page User Profile Page Admin Dashboard Needs and Donations Management Interface 3.3.2 Hardware Interfaces The application will run on standard web servers and client devices (desktops, tablets, smartphones). 3.3.3 Software Interfaces Google Maps API for map functionality Email service API for user notifications 3.3.4 Communication Interfaces HTTPS for secure data transmission RESTful APIs for interaction between frontend and backend 3.3.5 Notification Interfaces Integration with email and push notification services to keep users informed about needs and donations. 4. Appendices 4.1 Glossary Charity Location: A specific place in need of donations. Pin: A marker on the map indicating a charity location. Category: A classification of needs (e.g., food, education, shelter). 4.2 Analysis Models Use case diagrams Entity-relationship diagrams Data flow diagrams Technical Adjustments for AI Coding Assistant 1. Backend Technologies and Frameworks Programming Language: C# (.NET Core) Framework: ASP.NET Core Database: SQL Server with Entity Framework Core for ORM Authentication: JWT for user authentication 2. Frontend Technologies and Frameworks Framework: Angular Styling: Bootstrap for responsive design State Management: NgRx or Angular Services 3. API Integration Google Maps API: For map functionality and location services Email Service API: SendGrid or Amazon SES for email notifications Push Notification Service: Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM) 4. Security Measures Encryption: SSL/TLS for data in transit, AES for data at rest Authentication: Secure user authentication using JWT Data Protection: Regular security audits and compliance with GDPR-like regulations 5. Performance and Scalability Load Balancing: Nginx as a reverse proxy and load balancer Caching: Use Redis for caching frequently accessed data Horizontal Scaling: Docker and Kubernetes for containerization and orchestration Revised SRS with Technical Information To incorporate the above adjustments, the SRS sections can be updated as follows:
2.4 Operating Environment Web browsers: Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge Server: Linux-based server with Apache or Nginx Database: SQL Server for relational data, Redis for caching APIs: Google Maps API for location services 3.3 External Interface Requirements 3.3.3 Software Interfaces Google Maps API for map functionality SendGrid or Amazon SES for email notifications Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM) for push notifications 3.3.4 Communication Interfaces HTTPS for secure data transmission RESTful APIs for interaction between frontend (Angular) and backend (ASP.NET Core) 3.2 Non-Functional Requirements 3.2.4 Scalability Requirements The system architecture must support horizontal scaling using Docker and Kubernetes for containerization and orchestration.

Can this functions be implement inside the GetAllLocations user story?

We can modify the existing GetLocationsAsync method in the LocationService to include optional parameters for filtering and searching. This way, the same endpoint can be used for getting all locations, searching, and filtering, making the API more efficient and easier to use.
This integration would streamline the process for frontend developers, as they would only need to work with a single endpoint for various location retrieval scenarios. It's a great way to enhance the functionality while maintaining a clean and intuitive API design.

Microsoft.Data.SqlClient.SqlException (0x80131904): Introducing FOREIGN KEY constraint 'FK_LocationFeedbacks_Users_UserId' on table 'LocationFeedbacks' may cause cycles or multiple cascade paths. Specify ON DELETE NO ACTION or ON UPDATE NO ACTION, or modify other FOREIGN KEY constraints. Could not create constraint or index.

I understand the issue you're facing. This error occurs when there are multiple cascade paths in your database schema, which can lead to ambiguous delete or update operations.
To resolve this, we need to modify the foreign key constraint for the LocationFeedbacks table. We can do this by specifying ON DELETE NO ACTION in the relationship between LocationFeedbacks and Users.
In your ApplicationDbContext class, add the following configuration in the OnModelCreating method:
```csharp protected override void OnModelCreating(ModelBuilder modelBuilder) { base.OnModelCreating(modelBuilder);
modelBuilder.Entity<LocationFeedback>() .HasOne(lf => lf.User) .WithMany() .HasForeignKey(lf => lf.UserId) .OnDelete(DeleteBehavior.NoAction); } ```
This configuration tells Entity Framework Core to use NO ACTION for delete operations on this foreign key, which should resolve the multiple cascade paths issue.
After making this change, update your database by creating and applying a new migration. This should allow the foreign key constraint to be created successfully.
